titlestmt.titleproper: Collection of material about Japanese American incarceration
Finding Aid for the Collection of Material about Japanese American Incarceration LSC.0131
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Christen Sasaki, 2005; updated by Rishi Guné and Kuhelika Ghosh, 2019.

p.date: Online finding aid last updated 2021 May 27.

address.addressline: Room A1713, Charles E. Young Research Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-01-17 15:48:12 -0800.

did.unittitle: Collection of Material about Japanese American incarceration
did.abstract: The collection consists of publications and press releases by the United States War Relocation Authority (WRA), in addition to yearbooks and pamphlets created by Japanese American incarcerees and advocacy groups, with an emphasis on the Manzanar and Minidoka incarceration camps.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

dao.xlink:title: Collection of Material about Japanese American Incarceration (44 items)

daodesc.p: Collection of Material about Japanese American Incarceration (44 items)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the physical objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Materials are not currently available for access and will require further processing and assessment. If you have questions about this material please email spec-coll@library.ucla.edu.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Ralph P. Merritt, 1946. Additional items are the gift of Bradford Smith, 1952.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Collection of material about Japanese American incarceration (Collection 131). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

The materials in Collection 131 were extracted from Collection 122, the Manzanar War Relocation Center records (formerly titled the U.S. War Relocation Authority Archive) in 1971, when that collection was arranged and described. The materials were given summary description in 1979.

Further processing was performed by Christen Sasaki, with assistance from Laurel McPhee, in the Center for Primary Research and Training, in 2005. Items were inventoried, housed in folders, and arranged into series to enhance access to the collection. A machine-readable finding aid created by Caroline Cubé and edited by Josh Fiala, Laurel McPhee, and Amy Shung-Gee Wong.

Description updates were undertaken by Rishi Guné and Kuhelika Ghosh as part of a 2019 CFPRT Redescription Project. Euphemistic terms such as "internment" were updated to reflect preferred terminology outlined in the Power of Words Handbook from the Japanese American Citizens League.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection consists primarily of materials from the United States War Relocation Authority related to Japanese Americans and forced removal. Included are various War Authority publications and pamphlets; The Minidoka irrigator, a weekly newspaper published at the Minidoka Relocation Center (Hunt, Idaho); camp newsletters from Puyallup Assembly Center (unofficially called Camp Harmony); and miscellaneous publications related to the Manzanar inconcentration camp in Owens Valley, CA. In addition are yearbooks and pamphlets created by Japanese American incarcerees and advocacy groups, such as the Japanese American Citizens League (JACL), with an emphasis on the Manzanar and Minidoka incarceration camps; and speeches, clippings of published articles, and Master's theses. The collection also includes a recording of The Exile's Return, a production of CBS-KNX News (1956) and several reproduced sketches by artist Mine Okubo.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Arranged in the following series:
War Relocation Authority (WRA), 1942-1946
Incarceration camps, 1942-1945
Miscellaneous, 1929-1956.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Manzanar War Relocation Center records (Collection 122). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

Japanese American Research Project collection of material about Japanese in the United States (Collection 2010). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

did.unittitle: Series 1: War Relocation Authority (WRA)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Publications and speeches sponsored by the War Relocation Authority (WRA). Includes annual and semi-annual reports for the years 1942 through 1946, assorted pamphlets advocating Japanese American incarceration, resettlement, and enlistment in the armed forces, and transcripts of speeches by Dillon S. Myer, Director of the WRA.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: This series has been digitized. Digital reproductions of materials in this series are available online at https://digital.library.ucla.edu/catalog/ark:/21198/z1wm32vb .

did.unittitle: Quarterly report

dao.xlink:title: Quarterly report

daodesc.p: Quarterly report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report includes chronology detailing incarceration process from 1941 December 7 to 1942 June 29 and gives brief descriptions of incarceration camp sites.

did.unittitle: Quarterly report

dao.xlink:title: Quarterly report

daodesc.p: Quarterly report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report covers employment statistics within incarceration camps, leave regulations, college student forced removal, and general aspects of life in incarceration camps, such as education, mess operations, religious activities, and the fears and anxieties of incarcerees.

did.unittitle: Quarterly report

dao.xlink:title: Quarterly report

daodesc.p: Quarterly report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report covers general aspects of life in incarceration camps, including forced removal progress, employment of incarcerees, and repatriation. Included is a description of a strike at the Potson camp and a riot at Manzanar.

did.unittitle: Semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report covers general aspects of life in incarceration camps, including mess hall operations, recreation, and education. Also details Senate Sub-committee investigation, Spanish Consular visit, isolation procedures, and segregation procedures for pro-Japanese and pro-American incarcerees.

did.unittitle: Semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report covers general aspects of life in incarceration camps, including segregation process and problems. Details Tule Lake Incident and November 1 demonstration at Tule Lake Hospital. Fold-out map of Tule Lake included.

did.unittitle: Semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Documents the WRA's transfer from independent war agency to Department of the Interior. Includes general description of life in incarceration camps, including reaction of incarcerees and enlistment. Includes report of the House Sub-Committee on the Tule Lake Incident, the closing of the Jerome Relocation Center, and tables and charts showing average incarceration camp populations.

did.unittitle: Semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report discussed resettlement procedures, housing problems, incarceree attitudes, the children's village at Manzanar, and labor attitudes of the Congress of Industrial Organizations (CIO) and the American Federation of Labor (AFL). Details the West Coast opposition toward Japanese American resettlement, including boycotts, terrorist incidents, and legal issues regarding ownership of property.

did.unittitle: Semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report summarizes resettlement, liquidation, and departure process from various incarceration camps. Resettlement issues of Tule Lake incarcerees are discussed, including renunciants and the declining influence of the Hoshidan (pro-Japanese societies).

did.unittitle: Final semi-annual report

dao.xlink:title: Final semi-annual report

daodesc.p: Final semi-annual report

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report documents the end of the WRA, as of June 30, 1946, including the forced removal of Tule Lake residents; renunciant hearings; closing of Tule Lake; and a general summary of incarceration processes.

did.unittitle: Address. Ben Kuroki

dao.xlink:title: Address. Ben Kuroki

daodesc.p: Address. Ben Kuroki

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address by Sergeant Ben Kuroki, U.S. Army Air Force, before the Commonwealth Club, San Francisco, CA (sponsored by the WRA). Details Kuroki's experience with racial prejudice while in the army, and calls for the humane treatment of Japanese Americans in the future. Kuroki was previously awarded with two Distinguished Flying Cross Medals.

did.unittitle: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "One Thousandth of A Nation"

dao.xlink:title: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "One Thousandth of A Nation"

daodesc.p: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "One Thousandth of A Nation"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address by the Director of the WRA, before a joint meeting of civic organizations in Salt Lake City, UT. Includes descriptions of life in the incarceration camps, and argues for the resettlement of Japanese Americans.

did.unittitle: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Problems of Evacuee Resettlement in California"

dao.xlink:title: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Problems of Evacuee Resettlement in California"

daodesc.p: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Problems of Evacuee Resettlement in California"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address by the Director of the WRA in Eagle Rock, CA. Provides brief overview of forced removal process after 1943 and argues for resettlement of Japanese Americans.

did.unittitle: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Relocation Problems and Policies"

dao.xlink:title: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Relocation Problems and Policies"

daodesc.p: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "Relocation Problems and Policies"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address by the Director of the WRA, before the Tuesday Evening Club in Pasadena, CA. Details the operations of the incarceration centers in response to Hearst newspapers' claims that incarcerees were coddled; Meyer also contends that Japanese Americans must be protected and allowed to resettle.

did.unittitle: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "The Facts About the War Relocation Authority"

dao.xlink:title: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "The Facts About the War Relocation Authority"

daodesc.p: Address. Dillon S. Myer. "The Facts About the War Relocation Authority"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Address by the Director of the WRA, before a luncheon meeting of the Los Angeles Town Hall, Los Angeles, CA.

unittitle.title: Community Government in War Relocation Centers

dao.xlink:title: Community Government in War Relocation Centers

daodesc.p: Community Government in War Relocation Centers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on the development of internal governments run by incarcerees. Subjects include the problems and confusion surrounding the Poston Strike and Manzanar Riot, community organization, and the future of Japanese American communities.

unittitle.title: The Evacuated People: A Quantitative Description

dao.xlink:title: The Evacuated People: A Quantitative Description

daodesc.p: The Evacuated People: A Quantitative Description

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on the experiences of incarcerees at incarceration camps, moving, segregation, settling into camps, and resettlement.

unittitle.title: Impounded People: Japanese Americans in the Relocation Centers

dao.xlink:title: Impounded People: Japanese Americans in the Relocation Centers

daodesc.p: Impounded People: Japanese Americans in the Relocation Centers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on constitutional issues involved in the forced removal process, the WRA's legal framework, and the organization of the Office of the Solicitor.

unittitle.title: Legal and Constitutional Phases of the WRA Program

dao.xlink:title: Legal and Constitutional Phases of the WRA Program

daodesc.p: Legal and Constitutional Phases of the WRA Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet designed to ease agitation and anti-Japanese American sentiment. Questions addressed include: Japanese religion and ties to emperor, Japanese Language Schools, Nisei (a person born in the US or Canada whose parents were immigrants from Japan) in the Army, honesty of the Japanese as a race, assimilability of the Japanese, agricultural Competition, and coddling by the WRA.

did.unittitle: "Message from the National Director to the Residents of Relocation Centers"

dao.xlink:title: "Message from the National Director to the Residents of Relocation Centers"

daodesc.p: "Message from the National Director to the Residents of Relocation Centers"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Open letter instructing incarcerees about resettlement, including timely departure from incarceration camps and camp closing dates.

unittitle.title: Myths and Facts About the Japanese Americans: Answering Common Misconceptions Regarding Americans of Japanese Ancestry

dao.xlink:title: Myths and Facts About the Japanese Americans: Answering Common Misconceptions Regarding Americans of Japanese Ancestry

daodesc.p: Myths and Facts About the Japanese Americans: Answering Common Misconceptions Regarding Americans of Japanese Ancestry

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted newspaper articles on the bravery and sacrifices of Japanese American soldiers in World War II. Newspapers include Los Angeles Times, Tacoma News-Times, Chicago Tribune, and Omaha World Herald.

unittitle.title: Nisei in the War Against Japan

dao.xlink:title: Nisei in the War Against Japan

daodesc.p: Nisei in the War Against Japan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Illustrated pamphlet on Japanese Americans in the 442nd Regimental Combat Team and 100th Battalion. Includes an article about Ben Kuroki, the only American of Japanese descent in the United States Army Air Forces to serve in combat operations in the Pacific theater of World War II.

unittitle.title: Nisei in Uniform

dao.xlink:title: Nisei in Uniform

daodesc.p: Nisei in Uniform

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet on the segregation of Tule Lake incarcerees, including living conditions, improvement in public attitudes, and the records of Japanese American soldiers.

did.unittitle: Press releases

dao.xlink:title: Press releases

daodesc.p: Press releases

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: WRA press releases on subjects related to incarcerees. Two items commemorate the military service of Japanese Americans, including the 110th Battalion and the 442nd Regimental Combat Team.

unittitle.title: Relocating Japanese Americans

dao.xlink:title: Relocating Japanese Americans

daodesc.p: Relocating Japanese Americans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statistics on incarcerees, including marriage and divorce rates, numbers of renunciants, population at Tule Lake, and age composition of incarceration camp populations. Gift of Bradford Smith.

unittitle.title: The Relocation Program

dao.xlink:title: The Relocation Program

daodesc.p: The Relocation Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Historic overview of the WRA and events leading to its creation. Includes early incarceration policies, forced removal processes, and resettlement. Gift of Bradford Smith.

unittitle.title: The War Relocation Work Corps: A Circular of Information for Enlistees and Their Families

dao.xlink:title: The War Relocation Work Corps: A Circular of Information for Enlistees and Their Families

daodesc.p: The War Relocation Work Corps: A Circular of Information for Enlistees and Their Families

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet for Japanese Americans about incarceration camps, including family life, health, education, household effects, and the War Relocation Work Corps.

unittitle.title: Wartime Exile: The Exclusion of the Japanese Americans From the West Coast

dao.xlink:title: Wartime Exile: The Exclusion of the Japanese Americans From the West Coast

daodesc.p: Wartime Exile: The Exclusion of the Japanese Americans From the West Coast

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on the justification for incarceration of Japanese and Japanese Americans, including a history of Japanese travels to North America beginning 1610, and general descriptions of Japanese and Japanese American populations in San Francisco, Los Angeles, Sacramento, Portland, and Seattle. Gift of Bradford Smith.

unittitle.title: The Wartime Handling of Evacuee Property

dao.xlink:title: The Wartime Handling of Evacuee Property

daodesc.p: The Wartime Handling of Evacuee Property

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on property issues created by incarceration, including the raid on Nichiren Temple, Los Angeles. Gift of Bradford Smith.

unittitle.title: War Time Authority Community Government Handbook: A Summation of the Functions, Organization, and Relocationships of the Council of Administration

dao.xlink:title: War Time Authority Community Government Handbook: A Summation of the Functions, Organization, and Relocationships of the Council of Administration

daodesc.p: War Time Authority Community Government Handbook: A Summation of the Functions, Organization, and Relocationships of the Council of Administration

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Summary of the organization, techniques, function, and objectives of incarceration camp Community Councils in 1942-1943.

unittitle.title: "What We're Fighting For": Statements by United States Servicemen about Americans of Japanese Descent

dao.xlink:title: "What We're Fighting For": Statements by United States Servicemen about Americans of Japanese Descent

daodesc.p: "What We're Fighting For": Statements by United States Servicemen about Americans of Japanese Descent

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet attesting to the loyalty of Nisei soldiers.

did.unittitle: Series 2: Incarceration camps

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Small publications, including yearbooks and newsletters, written and produced by Japanese American incarcerees from the Manzanar and Minidoka incarceration camps, and the Camp Harmony temporary detention center in Puyallup, Washington.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: This series has been digitized. Digital reproductions of materials in this series are available online at https://digital.library.ucla.edu/catalog/ark:/21198/z1wm32vb .

unittitle.title: A Barrack Becomes A Home: A Cooperative Project in Homemaking by the Students of the Home Economics and Woodshop Departments of the Manzanar Secondary School

dao.xlink:title: A Barrack Becomes A Home: A Cooperative Project in Homemaking by the Students of the Home Economics and Woodshop Departments of the Manzanar Secondary School

daodesc.p: A Barrack Becomes A Home: A Cooperative Project in Homemaking by the Students of the Home Economics and Woodshop Departments of the Manzanar Secondary School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet prepared by Beatrice White, Home Economics Supervisor, Manzanar Secondary Schools, documenting class projects. Includes photographs of a typical Manzanar barrack interior and of altered barracks.

did.unittitle: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 4-8 (complete run)

dao.xlink:title: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 4-8

daodesc.p: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 4-8

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Camp Harmony Assembly Center newsletter, Puyallup, Washington. Includes articles on daily life in the incarceration camp, such as conditions, sports, school, the temporary detention center, and employment.

did.unittitle: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 9-11 (complete run)

dao.xlink:title: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 9-11

daodesc.p: Camp Harmony Newsletter, v. I no. 9-11

unittitle.title: Education Section Summary

dao.xlink:title: Education Section Summary

daodesc.p: Education Section Summary

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on the closing of Manzanar's education system, prepared for Ralph P. Merritt for the WRA. Includes brief overview of pre-school, elementary, secondary school, adult education programs, and library systems. Final page includes signatures of Manzanar education staff. Cover artwork by Takamura, 1942.

unittitle.title: Lil Dan'l: One Year In A Relocation Center

dao.xlink:title: Lil Dan'l: One Year In A Relocation Center

daodesc.p: Lil Dan'l: One Year In A Relocation Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Limited edition pictorial review documenting the first year of life in the Rohwer incarceration camp. Designed and illustrated by George Akimoto.

did.unittitle: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Cardinal and Gold"

dao.xlink:title: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Cardinal and Gold"

daodesc.p: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Cardinal and Gold"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soft cover yearbook for the Manzanar incarceration camp graduating class of summer 1943.

did.unittitle: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Our World: Manzanar, California"

dao.xlink:title: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Our World: Manzanar, California"

daodesc.p: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Our World: Manzanar, California"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hardcover yearbook for the Manzanar incarceration camp graduating class of 1944. Illustrated.

did.unittitle: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Valediction"

dao.xlink:title: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Valediction"

daodesc.p: Manzanar High School Yearbook, "Valediction"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Soft cover yearbook for the Manzanar incarceration camp graduating class of 1945. Illustrated.

unittitle.title: Manzanar Libraries and Visual Aid Program

dao.xlink:title: Manzanar Libraries and Visual Aid Program

daodesc.p: Manzanar Libraries and Visual Aid Program

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report prepared by Ruth Budd, Director of School and Community Libraries. Report covers library history, staff training, fiction library, high school and elementary division. Includes black and white photographs of staff and facilities.

did.unittitle: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 15-20 (complete run)

dao.xlink:title: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 15-20

daodesc.p: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 15-20

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Minidoka incarceration camp newsletter. Includes articles on daily life in the camp, such as conditions, sports, school, and employment. Also includes a Japanese Language section on the back page with a brief English guide.

did.unittitle: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 4-14 (incomplete run)

dao.xlink:title: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 4-14

daodesc.p: Minidoka Irrigator, v. I no. 4-14

did.unittitle: Senior Edition: The Spot, v. III no. 7

dao.xlink:title: Senior Edition: The Spot, v. III no. 7

daodesc.p: Senior Edition: The Spot, v. III no. 7

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Student newsletter from Manzanar. Includes senior class wills of last graduating class from Manzanar High.

unittitle.title: Toy Loan Library

dao.xlink:title: Toy Loan Library

daodesc.p: Toy Loan Library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet on the Manzanar Toy Loan Project, began in 1944. Topics include founding, organization, objectives, floor plan, and mimeographed forms used by the Center. Booklet also includes six black and white photographs of children at the Toy Loan Center.

did.unittitle: Trek, v. 1 no. 1.

dao.xlink:title: Trek, v. 1 no. 1

daodesc.p: Trek, v. 1 no. 1

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Special publication of Reports Division, Central Utah Relocation Project (Topaz), compiled by camp incarcerees. Consists of short stories, essays, and a biographical sketch of Mine Okubo. Includes artwork by Mine Okubo.

did.unittitle: Series 3: Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains assorted printed materials including articles, publications, and clippings; a World War II recruiting poster; speeches; and Master's theses. Also included is a recording of a radio broadcast. Creators include the Japanese American Citizens League (JACL), the American Council on Public Affairs, the Fellowship of Reconciliation, and various individuals.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Materials will require assessment and may need further processing for safe access. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

did.unittitle: Audio recording: "Minority Report III: The Exile's Return"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Two 10-inch vinyl records encompassing Parts 1-4 of a special report on the Japanese American community in Los Angeles. Originally broadcast over KMX on July 1, 1956 (production of CBS-KNX News in cooperation with The Fund For The Republic).

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS UNPROCESSED AUDIO MATERIALS: Materials will require assessment and may need further processing for safe access. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

did.unittitle: Carter, Genevieve. "Child Care and Youth Problems In A Relocation Center"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from the Journal of Consulting Psychology (v. III no. 4), p. 219-225. Topics include the influence of the non-citizen parents on their citizen children, youth and delinquency, and the problems of younger children.

did.unittitle: Casey, Gene. "G.I. Japyank"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprinted by the WRA, with permission from Collier's. Includes interview with Private Mac Yazawa.

did.unittitle: Clark, Blake and Russell, Oland. "Hail Our Japanese-American GIs!"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Condensed reprint from the American Mercury. Describes heroic acts by members of the 100th Infantry Battalion and the 442nd Infantry Regiment.

unittitle.title: The Displaced Japanese-Americans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pamphlet published by the American Council on Public Affairs; text originally appeared in Fortune, April 1944, under the title "Issei, Nisei, and Kibei." Defends the position of WRA against the Hearst newspapers, and describes life of the incarcerees. Calls for protection of civil liberties. Includes artwork by Mine Okubo.

did.unittitle: Excerpts and clippings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Excerpts from American newspapers regarding Japanese Americans. Newspapers include: The Courier (Camden, NJ); Arizona Republic (Phoenix, AZ); The Register (Des Moines, Iowa); The Tribune (Cheyenne, WY); The Record (Philadelphia, PA); Salt Lake Tribune (Salt Lake City, UT); Herald and American (Chicago, IL). Topics include employment, Nisei volunteers in the armed forces, and Japanese American resentment of Japanese brutality to prisoners of war.

did.unittitle: Foote, Caleb. Outcasts! The Story of America's Treatment of Her Japanese-American Minority

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Illustrated pamphlet. Text questions the constitutionality of incarceration, citing racial prejudice and political pressure as the dominant forces behind incarceration; describes life in the camps. loyalty, and assimilation issues.

did.unittitle: "Hawaii Soldiers Died Fighting As Loyal Americans, Col. Fielder Says"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of an address delivered by Col. Kendall Fielder on the presentation of Purple Hearts to the families of 60 Japanese American soldiers killed in action in Italy. Photographic illustrations, with an article by Elmont Waite describing the ceremony.

did.unittitle: "Klu-Kluxism on the West Coast"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Illustrated article from Collier's, denouncing the Japanese American Exclusion League.

did.unittitle: Message from the President of the United States: "Segregation of Loyal and Disloyal Japanese in Relocation Centers"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Message before the 78th Congress, 1st session, transmitting a report on Senate resolution no. 166 relating to segregation of loyal and disloyal Japanese in incarceration camps.

did.unittitle: Morimitsu, George. "These Are Our Parents"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from the Oct. 1943 issue of Asia and the Americas. Details the cultural and generational gap between Isei and Nisei, beliefs and values of Isei.

did.unittitle: Nishimura, M.S., et al. "The Propagation of Guayule from Cuttings"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from the American Journal of Botany (v. 31 no. 7), p. 412-418.

did.unittitle: O'Brien, Robert. "Reaction of the College Nisei to Japan and Japanese Foreign Policy"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from the Pacific Northwest Quarterly (v. 36 no. 1). Article on the experience of Nisei college students before the bombing of Pearl Harbor, and their reaction to recruitment efforts of Japanese government.

did.unittitle: O'Brien, Robert. "Selective Dispersion As a Factor in the Solution of the Nisei Problem"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from Social Forces (v. 22 no. 2). Article examines dispersion of second generation Japanese Americans through college education as solution to assimilation process.

did.unittitle: Rice, Richard B. The Manzanar Relocation Center

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thesis. Attempts to trace the forces which created a democratic way of life in Manzanar. Topics covered include forced removal, WRA, Relocation Program, early history of Manzanar, employment problems at camp, problems with community government, and special projects.

did.unittitle: Spier, Leslie. "Growth of Japanese Children Born in America and Japan"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Reprint from the University of Washington Press, University of Washington Publications in Anthropology (v. 3 no. 1), p. 1-30. Topics include observations of body characteristics of Japanese children born in the United States and Japan such as length of head, width of face, and average age of loss of teeth.

did.unittitle: Sproul, Robert Gordon. Address: "The test of a free country..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copies of a speech by Dr. Robert Gordon Sproul, President of the University of California, at the California Club, Los Angeles, Calif. for the Pacific Coast Committee on American Principles and Fair Play.

did.unittitle: Stearns, Marjorie. The History of the Japanese People in Oregon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: University of Oregon Thesis Series. Topics include settlement of the Japanese in Oregon, relations between the Japanese and white residents, and anti-Japanese legislation.

did.unittitle: Tatsumi, Henry S. Language Maps: Comparative Syntactic Charts for Japanese and English

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Visual aid illustrating the patterns of Japanese and English language structure.

unittitle.title: They Work for Victory: The Story of Japanese Americans and the War Effort

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Illustrated promotional pamphlet published by the Japanese Americans Citizens League (JACL). Advocates the efforts of Nisei, specifically service in armed forces and Nisei women working in manufacturing plants. Includes photographs of sculptor Isamu Noguchi and Ballerina Sono Osato.

did.unittitle: Town Meeting, v. 11 no. 21. Transcript: "Who Should Control the Atomic Bomb?"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Transcript of radio broadcast sponsored by the American Broadcasting Company. Moderated by George V. Denny, Jr. Speakers: Raymond Swing, Hanson Baldwin, Owen Brewster, and Edward R. Murrow.

did.unittitle: United States. Dept. of the Interior. Division of Budget and Administrative Management. People in Motion: The Postwar Adjustment of the Evacuated Japanese Americans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Report on incarceration, public acceptance and attitudes toward resettlement, economic adjustment of incarcerees, forced removal loss and remedial legislation, and social adjustment. Gift of Bradford Smith.

did.unittitle: Yoshida, Shigeo. In Memoriam: An Address in Honor of the University of Hawaii Varsity Victory Volunteers Who Died In World War II

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: University of Hawaii Occasional Paper 44, Honolulu. Includes brief history of the Varsity Victory Volunteers, by Margaret Blegen.

did.unittitle: Poster, "Miles of Hell To Tokyo"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: World War II recruiting poster published by the War Manpower Commission. Text reads: "Miles of Hell to Tokyo! Work Where You're Needed: Consult Your U.S. Employment Service Office." Illustration by Amos Sewell.
